content.description: The north face is a bit more adventurous than the east face. Crack is still adequate, but there tends to be birds nests and flaring more than tasty splitters. Still a worthwhile lead or toprope if you need another route to do up there.
content.protection: A single set of cams. I believe a number 4 camalot was used though not needed.
content.location: North face. Still good belay spot. Rap from slings.

content.description: The east face seems to have the best protection of the other 3 faces with the cleanest climbing, and a better belay spot, so it has become the standard route up the pinnacle. Climb up the face utilizing pro when you can get it in the horizontal cracks.
content.protection: A few cams. Most climbers place only 3-4 pieces in the .75 to 2 camalot region. The top section seems a little shy on pro, but nothing too runout or scary.
content.location: East face of the pinnacle. Rap from the 87 slings wrapped around the block on top.

content.description:
First bolt is visible at the base  on the north face

Climb past the first bolt using the arete

with good holds found up high.

if you’re taller easier to reach if you’re short it requires 5.10 a move to get to them. Their move up following the broken crack past the contributions from our furry friends to the beautiful exposed face above. Work straight up the mid face on some great features

. Just passed the fourth  bolt use the arete with your right hand for memorable holds. Climb up to the last bolt from there or you can use the sport chains or move left to top out for a beautiful view.  I top roped this back in 1984 so first ascent is unknown. I’m sure it was done before my time. Bolts  are now placed for our climbing pleasure.  Short exposed but very sweet.
